latestVersion.citationRequirements: Bolton, Frank G., Jr. MARICOPA COUNTY, ARIZONA STUDY OF CHILD MALTREATMENT RISK AMONG ADOLESCENT MOTHERS, 1976-1978 (computer file). Phoenix, AZ: Arizona Department of Economic Security, and Adolescent Parenting Program [producer], 1980. fields.value: Maricopa County, Arizona Study of Child Maltreatment Risk Among Adolescent Mothers, 1976-1978

otherIdAgency.value: Data Archive on Adolescent Pregnancy and Pregnancy Prevention

datasetContactAffiliation.value: University of California, Los Angeles. Social Science Data Archive.

dsDescriptionValue.value:
The purpose of this study was to determine whether the incidence of child maltreatment was higher among natural children born to adolescent mothers, compared to that obtained for children born to post-adolescent women.  Data are based on the National Clearinghouse on Child Abuse Central registry form.  The form collects details on all children and parents in the family in which abuse or neglect is suspected, and the role played by each parent and/or child.  Topics include age, gender, ethnicity and relationship of household members, stress factors in home, role of parent/child/perpetrator, marital status, whether or not abuse or neglect was substantiated.  A random sample of 5,098 observations was drawn from the child maltreatment cases referred to the Maricopa County unit of the Arizona Department of Economic Security's Child Protective Services between January 1, 1976 and December 31, 1978.  This sample represented one-half of the cases referred to the Maricopa County unit. The county sample was taken from an alphabetical file, by family name of the adult as reported from the National Clearing house on Child Abuse (NCCNA) Central Registry form. The sample included 247 (4.9%) cases with incomplete information. A "working sample" of 4,851 cases was based onc ases that included complete information on  mother's  and oldest child's age. The DAAPP data file contains all
5,098 cases to facilitate utilization of all cases when variables other than mother's and oldest child's age are being analyzed.

Subject: STANDARD DEPOSIT TERMS 1.0  Type: DATAPASS:TERMS:STANDARD:1.0  Notes: The UCLA Social Science Data Archive (“the Archive”) gives permission and any required licenses to Data-PASS to make the Content available for archiving, preservation and access (with permission of the Archive), within the Data Preservation Alliance for the Social Sciences ("Data-PASS") in accordance with the Data-PASS terms (the "Terms") of use (available from: http://www.icpsr.org/Data-PASS). Including permission to: (a) redisseminate copies of the Data Collection in a variety of distribution formats only according to the standard terms of use of the Archive; (b) promote and advertise the Data Collection in any publicity (in any form) for Data-PASS and the Archive; (c) describe, catalog, validate and document the Content; (d) store, translate, copy or re-format the Data Collection in any way to ensure its future preservation and accessibility, improve usability and/or protect respondent confidentiality; (e) incorporate metadata (cataloging information) or documentation regarding this study into public access catalogues. The Archive represents and warrants that the Content conforms to all Terms and that the Archive is lawfully entitled and has full authority to license Data-Pass to use the Materials in the ways described in the Terms.;

value: Frank G. Bolton, Jr., Roy H. Laner, and Sandra P. Kane. Child Maltreatment Risk Among Adolescent Mothers: A Study of Reported Cases. American Journal of Orthopsychiatry, 1980, 50, pp 489-504.
Individuals drawn from cases referred to the Maricopa county Child Protective Services.

fields.value: Arizona Department of economic Security and Adolescent Parenting Program

A random sample of 5,098 observations was drawn from the child maltreatment cases referred to the Maricopa County unit of the Arizona Department of Economic Security's Child Protective Services between January 1, 1976 and December 31, 1978.  This sample represented one-half of the cases referred to the Maricopa County unit. The county sample was taken from an alphabetical file, by family name of the adult as reported from the National Clearing house on Child Abuse (NCCNA) Central Registry form. The sample included 247 (4.9%) cases with incomplete information. A "working sample" of 4,851 cases was based onc ases that included complete information on  mother's  and oldest child's age. The DAAPP data file contains all 5,098 cases to facilitate utilization of all cases when variables other than mother's and oldest child's age are being analyzed.
The original file received from the principal investigator by DAAPPP contained alphabetic and numeric values.  DAAPPP converted all alphabetic to numeric and added value labels.
